_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Santa Fe Irrigation District A? R.E. Badger Filtration Plant is located at 18535 Aliso Canyon Road, Rancho Santa Fe, CA 92067.  The facility has developed a risk management program to address the federal Environmental Protection Agency Requirements.  Santa Fe Irrigation District A? R.E. Badger Filtration Plant is diligent in the handling of all chemicals and is dedicated to the safety of its employees and the neighboring community. Santa Fe Irrigation District A? R.E. Badger Filtration Plant staff is trained and utilizes equipment to monitor the facility and provide safeguards, while effectively and safely using chlorine and aqueous ammonia.
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION POLICIES
Santa Fe Irrigation District A? R.E. Badger Filtration Plant has a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training, reputable contractors, and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Chlorination Process.  Santa Fe Irrigation District A? R.E. Badger Filtration Plant policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. 
STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE
The Santa Fe Irrigation employs a chlorination system for final effluent disinfection using chlorine gas.  The chlorination system consists of a gaseous chlorine storage and feed system.  The gaseous chlorine is housed in the chlorine storage room.  The storage room contains eight scales, each configured with four one-ton chlorine cylinders, for a total of eight one-ton cylinders.  However, only four cylinders are utilized simultaneously, while the additional four are on stand-by.  Additionally, unconnected cylinders are stored on trunnions within the storage room.  Thus, a total of up to eight gaseous chlorine one-ton cylinders are located on site at any given time.
The aqueous ammonia system consists of a liquid storage tank outfitted with p

ressure relief valves containing 30% aqueous ammonia (ammonium hydroxide) solution.  Rather than using a metering pump, compressed air is supplied to the storage tank to maintain a slight positive pressure.  The aqueous ammonia is then fed at a small rate to the T.M. Vault Drip Line, F.M. Chamber Drip Line, and FCW Drip Line.
 
HAZARD ASSESSMENT SUMMARY/OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS
Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary
Scenario Description: Per the EPA Regulations, one worst case analysis has been defined for each covered process.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab in the CalARP/RMP/PSM Compliance Workbook.  
Alternative Release Scenarios Results Summary
Scenario Description: Two alternative case release scenarios were modeled.  The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation located behind the Hazard Assessment Tab in the CalARP/RMP/PSM Compliance Workbook. 
RISK CONSIDERATIONS
Although the storage and use of chlorine and aqueous ammonia has inherent potential risks, and worst case release scenarios can potentially reach the community; the facility has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst case type of event non-credible.  In addition to the safety practices of the company and plant personnel to make the worst case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event.
In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with a release of a regulated substance:
The system has alarms and interlocks
The system undergoes periodic maintenance to reduce the likelihood of catastrophic failures.
Gas detection i

s in place to notify individuals if a leak occurs.
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
As part of the implementation of this RMP Program, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by Santa Fe Irrigation to manage process safety issues associated with the use of chlorine and aqueous ammonia.  In addition, common industry standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being performed; this includes common practices outlined by the Chlorine Institute.  The Chlorine Prevention Program 3 elements include:
Process Safety Information
Process Hazard Analysis
Operating Procedures
Training
Mechanical Integrity
Management of Change
Pre-Startup Safety Review
Compliance Audits
Incident Investigation
Employee Participation
Hot Work Permit
Contractors
The Aqueous Ammonia Program 2 elements include:
Safety Information
Hazard Review
Operating Procedures
Training
Maintenance
Compliance Audits
Incident Investigation
FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
There have been no chlorine or aqueous ammonia releases within the last five years.  
EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM 
The facility has filed a Unified Contingency Plan with San Diego County Department of Environmental Health and this plan includes:
Emergency Alarm Procedures
Evacuation Procedures
Safety and Health Considerations
Notification Procedures
PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
A Process Hazard Analysis (PHA), Hazard Review, and Seismic Assessment have been conducted to examine mitigation measures to improve safety at the facility.  Planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the reports.  Any outstanding recommendations will have been addressed by December 30, 2009.  
FLAMMABLES: WORST CASE
The use of flammable materials at the Santa Fe Irrigation District A? R.E Badger Filtration Plant is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable. 
FLAMMABLES: ALTERNA

TIVE RELEASE
The use of flammable materials at the Santa Fe Irrigation District A? R.E Badger Filtration Plant is not encompassed by either the federal or state RMP requirements.  Therefore, this section is not applicable.
